snippet: Not only do the exchange programs reduce the spread of damaging viral infections, but they also have been shown to save money....
abstract: The Upshot; syringe exchange programs have been shown to be both safe and cost-efficient way to help reduce spread of viral infections among vulnerable populations of users of some drugs; despite consensus on their efficacy, programs have not proliferated largely due to misconception that they promote drug use and raise crime levels.

byline.contributor: Austin Frakt is a health economist with several governmental and academic affiliations. He blogs at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @afrakt.

lead_paragraph: Not only do the exchange programs reduce the spread of damaging viral infections, but they also have been shown to save money.

headline.print_headline: The Politics Are Hard, but Needle Exchanges Work
headline.main: Politics Are Tricky but Science Is Clear: Needle Exchanges Work
